title: Amazon is now offering Prime customers free one-day shipping on items that cost as little as $1
text:
Amazon is opening its doors wide to Prime customers in search of faster shipping in an effort to eat up more of the traditional retail market.

According to a report from Recode, the e-commerce giant has removed restrictions on its products that forbade customers from utilizing one-day shipping on items less than $5.

Prime customers will be now able to select one-day shipping on products that cost as little as $1, making routine trips to convenience stores that much less convenient.

Amazon is doing away with its policy of only shipping carts over a $5 subtotal by setting a $1 limit on products available with free one-day shipping (File photo)

While Amazon has long-sold products like deodorant, dental floss, and other household items on its platform, the restriction on price meant its users were usually required to buy those items in a larger set or tack them onto orders with other items through the company's 'add-on' program.

Recode notes, however, that Amazon's 'add-on' program has been slowly phased out in recent months, essentially paving the way for a new ere of single-use shopping.

Now, with the restrictions lifted, customers will be able to not only buy those items individually, but have them delivered imminently to their doorstep.

As reported by Recode, the move may have a profound impact on retailers like CVS or Target that often act as magnets for consumers searching for cheap everyday, often one-off, items.

'There’s no way that shipping costs are less than 75 cents, and there’s no way any other company that wants to sell a makeup brush could deliver that for free,' Sally Hubbard, a former New York State antitrust enforcer told Recode.

'It’s not possible and it highlights how pricing strategies can be used to drive rivals from the market... '

It's unclear whether the company can sustain the practice of shipping out products at a loss or whether merchants will ultimately reap the benefits (Stock image)

Though convenient for customers and brands looking to expand their market through Amazon, it's unclear how sustainable the company's new policy will be.

For one, shipping costs far outweigh the value of sending off a single toothbrush to a customer, meaning Amazon is likely losing money on every product sold under its new policy.

Recode also notes that Amazon has a habit of pressuring its merchants for reimbursement if products sold through the platform end up losing the company money.

'It’s been great for the manufacturers; they’re experiencing sales growth,' Andrea Leigh, a former Amazon executive told Recode.

'But I want to warn them all not to get too comfortable. In six months, Amazon is going to come back to you asking for money and could hold the brand hostage.'
description: The e-commerce giant has removed restrictions on its products that forbade customers from utilizing one-day shipping on items less than $5 and will now ship items that cost over $1.
